paper_title.en: Quantitative analysis of telomerase activity and telomerase reverse transoriptase expression in renal cell carcinoma
Two putative tumor suppressor genes on chromosome avan 8 may play different roles in prostate cancer
Effects of glucocorticoids on rat thymus and apoptosis
A pelvic abscess in a renal transplant recipient
Effects of tacrolimus on rat thymic epithelial cells
Inhibition of calpain but not caspase protects the testis against injury after experimental testicular torsion of rat

description.en: Testicular torsion requires emergent release of the twisted spermatic cord. Ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) plays an important role in its pathogenesis, and recent data suggest that germ cells undergo apoptosis during I/R. In a model of torsion/detorsion (i.e., I/R) of the rat testis, involvement of calpain and caspase in necrotic and apoptotic cell death was examined. After 1 h of ischemia followed by 0, 0.5, 1, 6, or 24 h of reperfusion, the germ cells positively stained with in situ TUNEL, and DNA fragmentation, activation of caspase-3, and proteolysis of caspase substrates increased with time of reperfusion, demonstrating apoptosis. In addition, m-calpain activation and proteolysis of alpha -fodrin were increased during reperfusion, and its activation is thought to be involved in the necrosis. A calpain inhibitor, acetyleucyl-leucyl-norleucinal, inhibited the phenomena associated with apoptosis and necrosis induced by I/R, although a caspase inhibitor, Z-Val-Ala-Asp-fluoromethlyketone, only inhibited apoptotic changes. The inhibition of calpain but not caspase ameliorated the injury after 60 days of reperfusion following 1 h of ischemia. The calpain inhibitor injected just before reperfusion effectively suppressed alpha -fodrin proteolysis, suggesting its usefulness in the treatment of testicular torsion.

paper_title.en: Expression of urinary cytokines during intravesical instillation therapy of BCG for carcinoma in situ of the urinary gladder

description.en: We measured various urinary cytokines such as IL-1beta, IL-2, IL-6, TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma in 10 patients treated with BCC; instillation immunotherapy for carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the urinary bladder and 4 patients with urinary tract infection (UTI). Spontaneously Voided urine was collected immediately before instillation of BCC and at 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and It hours, as well as during 12 to 24 hours thereafter. In patients with UTI spontaneously voided urine was collected on visiting our clinic. All samples were ultrafiltrated using an ADVANTEC UK-10 membrane (Toyo Roshi Company Ltd., Tokyo). Cytokines were measured by ELISA. In all patients with CIS there was no detectable concentration of cytokines in the urine before BCC instillation. During 24 hours after the first instillation of BCG, low concentration of IL-1beta, IL-6, IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha was detected. In contrast, at the eighth instillation all cytokines were detected in the urine. Especially significantly high concentration of TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma at the eight instillation was detected compared to that at the first instillation. The peak concentration of these cytokines was observed between 4 and 6 hours after the eighth instillation. In patients with UTI expression of IL-1 beta and IL-6 was the same as to that of the eight instillation therapy of BCC, however, concentration of IL-2, IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha was significantly lower than that of the eighth BCG instillation. It was suspected that IL-2, IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha induced by BCT may play an important role in the antitumor activity in BCC instillation immunotherapy.

paper_title.en: A case of synchronous cervical lymph node metastases from testicular and thyroid cancers showing mixed response to chemotherapy

description.en: We report a case of synchronous presentation of thyroid cancer and testicular seminoma with lymph node metastasis. A 37-year-old man presented with right scrotal swelling and multiple lymph node swelling. We performed right radical orchiectomy, and histological examination revealed a seminoma of the testis. After systemic work-up for staging, we diagnosed the patient with multiple lymph node metastasis of the seminoma, and administered three cycles of bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin (BEP) therapy. Although the chemotherapy was very effective for the retroperitoneal and left cervical lymph node metastases, the right cervical tumor did not change. Retroperitoneal lymphadenectomy combined with right cervical lymph node dissection and hemi-thyroidectomy were performed on September 8, 1998. Pathological examination of the thyroid revealed papillary thyroid cancer and its right cervical lymph node metastasis. There was no evidence of viable cancer cells from either of the primary cancers in the retroperitoneal lymph node. Unresponsiveness to chemotherapy for metastatic lesions from testicular cancer might be a useful clue to detect primary tumors of other origins.
